title: Despite legal troubles, artistic director optimistic about future of Manitoba Theatre for Young People
text:
If you go into a life in theatre, you had better be prepared for a little drama.
That was the experience of Pablo Felices-Luna, the 42-year-old, Peru-born theatre vet when he became the third artistic director of the Manitoba Theatre for Young People in November 2014.
One of the key theatrical institutions in Winnipeg, MTYP has been reeling since early 2013, when the company’s founding artistic director, Leslee Silverman — at the helm of the institution for 31 years — was unceremoniously terminated by the board of directors just two years after being awarded the Governor General’s Performing Arts Award for lifetime artistic achievement.
Interim artistic director Derek Aasland shrank the 2013-14 season to five productions and kept the company going, before suddenly resigning in May of last year after 16 months on the job.
This week’s opening of Danny, King of the Basement sees the beginning of Felice-Luna’s first true season as artistic director. The joy of that commencement might have been somewhat deflated with the news in early September that Silverman would be suing the company she founded for wrongful dismissal.
Sitting in his MTYP office in the quirky Forks theatre that Silverman built, Felices-Luna gingerly handles the question about the institution’s impending courtroom drama.
"The matter is before the courts and it will be seen through," he says.
"I can tell you I still love and respect Leslee. I think she’s an artist and a visionary and, because I’m an optimist, I think once this matter has seen its way through the courts, we will be at the other side of this difficult time."
And if Felices-Luna will be obliged to help that process, he seems confident about the task.
"I’m a middle child," he says, "which means I’m a peacemaker."
WAYNE GLOWACKI / WINNIPEG FREE PRESS
'This is a special place and it’s so emotional to be a part of something that’s been built from the ground up to serve our audience in such a specific and beautiful way,' Pablo Felices-Luna said. Photo Store
For many reasons, Pablo Felices-Luna seems a perfect fit for MTYP. He has a rare combination of formidable smarts and great personal warmth. He is the father of three children, all under the age of seven, with wife Carrie Costello, herself a playwright and puppeteer.
"We met at the University of Victoria," Felices-Luna says. "She’s from northern B.C., so she was moving to the big city in Victoria and I was moving from Lima, seven million people, to a much smaller city."
Growing up in Lima, he describes his family as "eclectic."
"My dad is an engineer, my mom’s a social worker, my sister is a criminologist and my older brother is an exegesist," he says, furnishing an explanation for that last one: "An exegesist is someone who practises exegesis, a critical interpretation of a text.
"Rodolfo specialized in passages of the Gospel according to John in his doctorate, so he got to do fun things like learning biblical Greek," he says. "One of my favourite conversations was when we went through passages of the gospel that were written following the structure of classical Greek tragedy.
"It was a bit of a nerd-fest, to tell you the truth," he says. "All of my siblings have ended up in Canada and my parents are still in Peru."
Felices-Luna’s education included an early encounter with the Canadian mosaic.
"When I was 15, I went to an international school in British Columbia — 200 students living in the woods for two years in this incredible program, at one of the United World colleges, focused on creating peace and international understanding through collaboration and knowledge," he says.
"I went back home for a year and did some training with a theatre troupe there, and realized that I really wanted to train as a director. So I had the opportunity go back (to B.C.) and I did my undergraduate training at the University of Victoria, where I met my wife, then I went to Toronto to do my master’s at York."
Out of school, Felices-Luna landed an important internship at Carousel Players in St. Catharines, Ont., under Kim Seledy, a frequent Silverman creative partner.
"As part of that internship, I got to come to MTYP for two shows (in 2002)… and it was so mind-opening," he says. "It was a great six months, so I knew I wanted to work in theatre for young audiences.
"I ended up working in Roseneath Theatre in Toronto, which is another theatre for young audiences, with Davis S. Craig, who wrote season-opener Danny, King of the Basement. He was my mentor at Roseneath. And when Kim left the Carousel Players, the opportunity came to me to take over the company and it was a phenomenal 7½ years at Carousel.
"And now I’m here," he says, recalling coming to the city to be interviewed for the job last fall.
"I walked out of the building and I had to call Carrie in St. Catharines and say, ‘This is really happening.’
"This is a special place and it’s so emotional to be a part of something that’s been built from the ground up to serve our audience in such a specific and beautiful way."
If MTYP faces challenges ahead, Felices-Luna seems excited to meet them head-on.
"I don’t think anybody goes into theatre to take it easy," he says.
